en-us.learning_promise:
This unit introduces your students to Earth, Physical, and Life Science topics, which they’ll explore while helping Maria, Sofie, Leo, and Daniel investigate the ways people and animals understand and use the world around them. They’ll experience and explain how light reflects from objects and enters the eyes, which allows the object to be seen. They’ll explore how animals use internal and external structures to live, grow, and survive in the world. They’ll learn about energy from natural resources and how their use by humans affects the environment. They’ll also research ways to decrease the impact of natural Earth processes on humans. Finally, they’ll design and compare multiple solutions that show how patterns can be used to transfer information.  

Your students will also practice their social and emotional learning, such as self-regulation, persistence, empathy, self-awareness, and mindfulness with the main characters in the lesson stories.  

Before your students begin this unit, we recommend the following to support their building and programming skills and prepare them for the challenges in this unit: 
- Access the LEGO® Education SPIKE™ [App][1] or install it on classroom devices.  
- Complete the Tutorial Activities (under the Start menu item in the LEGO Education SPIKE App).
Try one or more of the lessons in the [Crazy Carnival Games](https://education.lego.com/en-us/lessons/spikeessential-crazy-carnival-games) unit
- In addition, find [professional development][2] support for hands-on learning, programming, and coding. (Create a free LEGO ID if you don’t have one.) 



 


  [1]: https://education.lego.com/en-us/downloads/spike-app/software
  [2]: https://pd.legoeducation.com/pages/37/homeroom-premium

lessons.lesson_description: Daniel finds something while exploring a dark cave. Can you help him see it better?
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Daniel finds something while exploring a dark cave. Can you help him see it better?

text.content: Daniel finds something while exploring a dark cave. Can you help him see it better?

How can we see objects in a dark environment? 
If the path of light to an object is blocked, how does that affect our ability to see it?
What can we do to see an object if light is blocked from it?

Build a model car to help Daniel see objects in the cave. 
Add a light to the front of his car.

code_stack.title: SPIKE Essential How Eyes See
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="12" ishorizontal="false" displaymonitorincludedimages="11"><variables></variables><block type="flipperevents_whenProgramStarts" id=")@}8dbDK%u:||JX)1BZf" x="-145" y="-185"><next><block type="flipperdisplay_ledMatrix" id="QI)c#H){8(7+z/{UER@{"><value name="PORT"><shadow type="flipperdisplay_custom-matrix-port" id="46E.WH2?XaO{A_|I;uab"><field name="field_flipperdisplay_custom-matrix-port">A</field></shadow></value><value name="MATRIX"><shadow type="flipperdisplay_custom-matrix" id="Ax?Ul=s@RCy){;EZ+HWd"><field name="field_flipperdisplay_custom-matrix">777777777</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: Program your model to show how a path of light lets an object be seen.
Use your model to explain how light reflected from an object enters the eyes so that we can see the object.
Use your model to explain why we can’t see the object when the path of light to it is blocked.
Update the model with a motor, and program the motor so that the car can move to a new location.
Show how the car’s location changes the path of light and our ability to see the object.
Explain if moving the car could help Daniel see the object better.
Great job!

teacher_support.things_you_will_need:
(one for every two students)
- LEGO® Education SPIKE™ Essential Set
- Device with the LEGO Education SPIKE App installed
- See Prepare - Materials

lessons.title: SPIKE Essential How Eyes See

lessons.lesson_description: Maria sees an elephant eating. She wonders about ways elephants can use their trunks. Help her learn.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Maria sees an elephant eating. She wonders about ways elephants can use their trunks. Help her learn.

text.content:
Maria sees an elephant eating. 
She wonders about ways elephants can use their trunks. 
Help her learn.
What are some internal and external structures of elephants?
What are some ways that elephants use their trunks?

How do trunks help elephants to survive?
How might other elephant structures help them survive?

Build an elephant with a moveable trunk. 
 Show Maria ways the elephant uses its trunk to survive.

text.content: Program your model. Show how the elephant uses its trunk to reach for food. Show how it can make elephant sounds.

Use your model to explain how an elephant’s trunk can reach high tree branches for food. 
How does this help the elephant grow?

Use your model to explain how an elephant can make a loud sound with its trunk. 
How does this help it communicate?

Think of an internal structure. 
Add new elements to the elephant model that stand for it.

Program the model.
Show how elephants use this structure to survive. 
Think about lungs, a stomach, or another idea.
Great job!

- Device with the LEGO Education SPIKE App installed

lessons.title: SPIKE Essential Animal Structures

lessons.lesson_description: Sofie finds a wind turbine. She wonders how it gets energy. What are other ways to get energy from nature to use again and again?
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Sofie finds a wind turbine. She wonders how it gets energy. What are other ways to get energy from nature to use again and again?

text.content:
Sofie finds a wind turbine. 
She wonders how it gets energy. 
What are other ways to get energy from nature to use again and again?

What kind of energy resource is wind? 
Why?

What makes energy renewable? 
Give some examples.

What makes it non-renewable? 
Give some examples.
How does using different kinds of energy resources change the environment?

Explore renewable and non-renewable energy. 
Use at least two sources. 
Explain one kind of renewable energy.

Create a model to show your learning.
Use the picture for ideas if you like.

code_stack.title: SPIKE Essential Energy Resources
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="12" ishorizontal="false" displaymonitorincludedimages="11"><variables></variables><block type="flipperevents_whenProgramStarts" id=")@}8dbDK%u:||JX)1BZf" x="-110" y="-174"><next><block type="control_forever" id="kK1*$%Jj/Yn10B7MHZ*%"><statement name="SUBSTACK"><block type="flipperdisplay_ledMatrixBrightness" id="{r9rf]u;As8np|fEpk1$"><value name="PORT"><shadow type="flipperdisplay_custom-matrix-port" id="9trxA0,zSXM4y~xE|ztz"><field name="field_flipperdisplay_custom-matrix-port">A</field></shadow></value><value name="BRIGHTNESS"><shadow type="math_number" id="5}T-[g)GI2o!c4]RUUQ)"><field name="NUM">75</field></shadow><block type="flippermotor_speed" id="QIaTW~)IlL|p.rnDQU[x"><value name="PORT"><shadow type="flippermotor_single-motor-selector" id="lyVK@KOBkyxF,@xBLU)}"><field name="field_flippermotor_single-motor-selector">A</field></shadow></value></block></value><next><block type="flipperdisplay_ledMatrix" id="$+.{~Mcxkw@Di+OOy.R@"><value name="PORT"><shadow type="flipperdisplay_custom-matrix-port" id="aeM*)C;YD*SqW4Fc!!mo"><field name="field_flipperdisplay_custom-matrix-port">A</field></shadow></value><value name="MATRIX"><shadow type="flipperdisplay_custom-matrix" id="GVzuwVXRJo2fxk#qPsWk"><field name="field_flipperdisplay_custom-matrix">777777777</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></statement></block></next></block></xml>

text.content:
Start to program your model.      Note for educators: 
For the he wind turbine model, please use the provided white USB cable to connect hubs and devices to make the sample program more stable.  
This will enable you to better see the data that show how the speed of the blades affects the light’s brightness and how this is similar to a turbine creating less or more electricity from wind.
Use your model to explain how it shows a kind of renewable energy and how people use this kind of energy.
Use your model to explain how using it helps the environment. How does it cause problems?

Keep building your model. 
Keep programming it.
Use it to share what you learned.
Great job!

(one for every two students)
- LEGO® Education SPIKE™ Essential Set
- Device with the LEGO Education SPIKE  App installed
- See Prepare - Materials

lessons.title: SPIKE Essential Energy Resources

lessons.lesson_description: Leo knows some places have earthquakes. To keep people safe, help him design buildings that won’t be destroyed by earthquakes.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Leo knows some places have earthquakes. To keep people safe, help him design buildings that won't be destroyed by earthquakes.

text.content:
Leo knows some places have earthquakes. 
To keep people safe, help him design buildings that won't be destroyed by earthquakes.

What shape buildings are least likely to be damaged by earthquakes? 
Why?

What building materials will hold up well to an earthquake’s shaking force? 
Why?
How can we design buildings to reduce the impacts of earthquakes on people?
Make a building and a shaking machine that works like an earthquake.
Use the machine to test if an earthquake will destroy your design.

code_stack.title: SPIKE Essential Prepare for Natural Hazard
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="12" ishorizontal="false" displaymonitorincludedimages="11"><variables></variables><comment id="//UENU{@0s9up68eL624" x="164" y="-142" h="158.51852416992188" w="223.70361328125">Start the testing from a low speed and then increase (50%, 75% and 100%)</comment><block type="flipperevents_whenProgramStarts" id="`Xek22Z0P~MfgV`2~duG" x="-195" y="-130"><next><block type="flippermotor_motorSetSpeed" id="c0#{EeqF}:ku{+i]7ns9"><value name="PORT"><shadow type="flippermotor_multiple-port-selector" id="bWKYo55{WFA?nE`2rAEt"><field name="field_flippermotor_multiple-port-selector">A</field></shadow></value><value name="SPEED"><shadow type="math_number" id="YlLA-)]#y{K}na8ySAWL"><field name="NUM">25</field></shadow></value><next><block type="flippermotor_motorStartDirection" id="$UZs*Ic2)96@VHOFzI,n"><value name="PORT"><shadow type="flippermotor_multiple-port-selector" id="h[QI.SQ$G|[-c$}DJ5^n"><field name="field_flippermotor_multiple-port-selector">A</field></shadow></value><value name="DIRECTION"><shadow type="flippermotor_custom-icon-direction" id="B+2oP.ti{ZSS4@yE1,@^"><field name="field_flippermotor_custom-icon-direction">clockwise</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: Program your model to shake the building at different motor speeds, starting low and then increasing the speed.

Each time, test and record how long the building stays standing. 
Do some building designs fall right away? Why?
Use your model and sketches to explain the building design.
Use your model and sketches to explain your testing results, including why the design worked or failed.

Notice the other designs in the class.
Which will best reduce the impacts of earthquakes on people?
Why?
Build and program your model to add an alarm that warns people an earthquake is coming.
Try the matrix light and flashing red lights.
Great job!

teacher_support.things_you_will_need:
(one for every two students)
 - LEGO® Education SPIKE™ Essential Set
 - Device with the LEGO Education SPIKE App installed
 - See Prepare - Materials

lessons.title: SPIKE Essential Prepare for Natural Hazards

lessons.lesson_description: Maria, Leo, Daniel, and Sofie use a special code to share ideas. Make your own code to communicate with your friends!
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Daniel, Sofie, Leo, and Maria use a special code to share ideas. Make your own code to communicate with your friends!

text.content:
Daniel, Sofie, Leo, and Maria use a special code to share ideas. 
Make your own code to communicate with your friends!
What are some ways that people use patterns to transfer information?

What might be some criteria for designing a code? 
What about constraints?

Create at least two different codes for sending words with the letters A through E. 
Write them down.
Build a model to send coded messages to your friends.

Program your model and test it. Which meets the criteria better?
See the example as inspiration.

text.content:
Share your progress model and explain.
How do your code designs use different patterns to transfer information?

Share your progress model and explain.
What criteria and constraints did you use?

Share your progress model and explain.
What were your test results from comparing the two code designs?

Share your progress model and explain.
Did your codes make it easy to share information? Why or why not?
Use your completed model to share your designs with the class.

Use your completed model to compare everyone’s designs. 
Are they easy to use? 
Fast? Accurate?
Use your completed model to choose the best code to communicate with your friends.
Great job!

en-us.title: SPIKE Essential Science Connections
en-us.unit_plan_description: Maria, Sofie, Leo, and Daniel want to explore the ways people and animals understand and use the world around them. Can you help them?
